Symlinking is mounting-agnostic on GNU/Linux (and i would suspect this is general property of unix-likes); this also has side effect that if you later mount source partition/drive to another point, your links will be broken. Hardlinking directories isn't supported and hardlinking across drives simply doesn't make any sense.

That said, some applications like to mess with symlinks. I think one variant of symlinking actually didn't work for me, although i don't remember whether i tried to link whole data/HASH/ directory or some files inside it.

It should be possible work around using bind mounts instead, because those are mostly invisible from application point of view. But then it's a bit more complex to setup...

Not learning mandarin yet, but learning 漢字 can be at times fun, at times boring memorizing. If you can translate a character into a story, that can be both fun and aid memorization. Also you get to have additional dimension of word interrelatedness. But at other times characters look like complex mishmash of radicals with no connection to the meaning

Mandarin also has tones, but i can't really comment on how hard / fun those are

@Moor: one of the problems is that character simplicity does not have a strong correspondence with popularity / simplicity of concepts. If you can dedicate at least some time every day (even 15min should be enough if you don't need to learn fast), you can try some spaced repetition program. Also, grammar is supposed to be fun, but i don't really know about it (besides mandarin being analytic language)
@Moor: also, if you're more into grammar than lexicon and/or actually using language, i recommend trying conlangs; lojban is, of course, my favourite, though `mi na tavla fo ra`
@Bite: you may want to have create a separate acc, if you're planning to be otherwise active here. Unfortunately, there's no selective blocklisting implemented

I haven't worked with self-signed ids, so i can't say for sure, but afaiu you need to add those allowed usernames / public keys into `permissions` section with `max_size` set to whatever limit you want to set. Setting aside legal difficulties, why would you want to restrict users to share your content however they like?
  
Personally i think "no license" is the ideal in ideal world, but in the situation we're currently in, it might be more effective to adopt some "legalized" strategy. For non-code content, i prefer CC-BY-SA / CC-BY / CC0/PD, depending on how restrictive you want to be towards potentially bad entities. But while choosing overly restrictive licenses which may seem to promote good, it easily harms people who're also using licenses, something more mainstream and less restrictive: they can't combine it with your work
  
On a side, the variety of "CC" licenses is really terrible. People consider CC as some sort of brand, while in reality CC-NC-ND is just a regular "free as in beer" license. You're proposing yet another incompatible, non-free license

@Moor: eh, but then all the difficulties *will* be legal difficulties of defining those p2p restrictions, no?
  
Of CC licenses, only those with SA (same attribution) are copyleft. Of which there's CC-BY-SA and the dreaded CC-BY-NC-SA (as i've explain once, i can understand desire of some people to use non-commercial license, but.. that's just breaks compatibility and stops creative usage)

> also, we (me at least) don't need to play nicely

Playing nicely with others who play nicely is a must if you want to bring a good change
@Moor: my point was that your license (as well as many "good will" licenses) is not playing nicely with people who have been creating and putting stuff under libre licenses

@Moor:

> ideologically motivated on this, not entirely morally

To me that looks like a strange way to put it. Doesn't every ideology considers itself ethically superior? And if some actions endorsed by it are going contrary to "common moral", there's always a reason why those actually are still a good moral actions in perspective

> much of the code would be tied to decentralized apps.

That could as well be an excuse to not reinvent licenses ;) (at least if i understand correctly that your logic here is that it'd be hardly useful outside of p2p)

1. any (creationist, anyway) theological philosophy should answer the question "what was god(s) doing before creating the world?". Without answering such questions, actually given explanations have no ground
  
2. using "nothing" as a substantialized concept looks cool, but makes little sense
  
3. the problem of "two kinds of freedom" which he explores and solves only exist so far as there is one determinable ethical path. And i don't think that the word "freedom" should be burdened with his second meaning these days; it already has enough other meanings. In terminology i'm used to, what he talks about is actually "freedom of will", but perhaps at the time of writing that meant something different (?)

4. historical perspective might be interesting

@Moor:

> did he substantialized "nothing"? he gave no essence and nothing to take from, only to add, which was freedom's side effects.

"Nothing" cannot *be* a source of something (because it cannot *be* in the first place). While we can say "nothing is the source of X" to mean X has no source (and there is similar construct in russian), Berdyayev takes deliberate effort to put "nothing" into objectified position and then connects "nothing which is the source of freedom" with "nothing from out of which god created the world", further confirming he thinks of "nothing" as something definite and "existing" (even if not "in the regular sense")
  
I'll comment on the rest later

@Moor: not sure if i see the difference between objectification and substantiation. I'm not well-versed in philosophical lingo, but my intuition is that every object is made of a substance
  
I could see "nothing" being used as a concept in a way that it would take a position of object or subject in a sentence, but not being "objectified". The same as "time" or indeed "freedom of will". But we don't say that something "is made from time" (besides, perhaps, larger quantities of time from smaller ones)
  
But essentially "nothing" is negation and/or indication of 0 quantity, it only exist as a logical/linguistic tool for our reasoning

> nothingness does not exist because we cannot prove it that it does

Nah, my point is rather that we construct this concept specifically as something which cannot exist. And if we reassign its meaning to something that can, the concept is still there, we just lose ability to name it or have to invent new names (this sort of things is somewhat unavoidable in physics, where "atom" changes its meaning from abstract concept to rather concrete one and then we discover the latter is not really atomic; but in philosophy we aren't dealing with such "discoveries")

@Moor:

> the objectification here is meant to 'make something into a thing' only as a metaphysical object, not a physical one.

> something like that.

Ok, i guess i'll leave it like that ;) "metaphysical objects" sounds weird to me, though

> in the end "nothingness" is not the point of the argument, it only follows to say that if freedom begins somewhere it must begin from a place where there is everything to choose, if so, nothing must exist, which is absurd. there must be potential for it to exist, and so for freedom.

Hmm, here's the thing: i disagree with the notion that referents of metaphysical concepts can begin somewhere or sometime. Which makes it hard for me to appreciate the whole range of metaphysics/philosophy which talks about universe being created / appearing on its own

> it must begin from a place where there is everything to choose, if so, nothing must exist

Still, i don't see how that follows. Even if we admit the first part, "nothing" is not part of "everything" (again, because it is not a substance/object), so there is no contradiction

Also, unqualified quantifiers lead to a lot of strange statements, so i think it's best to avoid them unless the underlying qualification is absolutely clear from the context. And unqualified quantifiers in the strict sense [do not make sense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russell%27s_paradox)

@Moor: the thing is that in some idealistic setting "metaphysical object" could refer to something quite real albeit non-material.
  
> but this is wholly metaphysical its purely a concept

I don't think metaphysics (as philosophy branch) should be taken lightly ;)

> math has a strong(er) relation to the real world.

Math is mostly a strict language of our thinking. But considering thinking is the only thing we've got to make sense of perception and build notion of real world, the relation is pretty strong (not necessarily in the straightforward way it sometimes gets applied); "real world" must obey math laws because that's the only way to construct it

PS: Ha-ha, i guess we're mostly done with.. just one thread
0net.eu.org (ex 43110.cf) , though it "pre-renders" js

> the ethical path was mostly derived from Christianity, good and truth

Still, even if we accept some common values, there is a point of view that there is only one way to act upon them (and anything else is just half-compliance at best), and there's pov that there are many

> what he added however was that the first kind of freedom, which is elementary to the second, was the way in which we act upon nothingness is meaningless and eventually hurtful, however with truth, and truth alone may lead to authoritarianism requiring freedom of will and the act of good and even evil to not be authoritarian (the first kind).
 
> so, there is a dialectic between the two kinds. also his point about the first kind and the contradiction with scarcity is very much observable.
 
> and that is mostly what i find it useful to talk about freedom (in some contexts), to have an environment where freedom takes place (the nothingness) and therefore to have rational freedom, to have freedom not for the sake of having it but to liberate ourselves rationally in the process.

> at least we can go back to those kinds of synthesis without solely talking about freedom in the abstract. 

In the end, i'm not sure it makes sense to speak of "the second kind" as a freedom at all. Yes, knowledge sort of gives you more possibilities to consider, but adhering to ethics or even "acting rationally" doesn't. Absolute rationality with absolute knowledge would leave no place for freedom. But modern physics says we can't have absolute knowledge; and math has some concerns to consider about absolute rationality.. but even beyond that, it might turn out to be rational to not be rational all the time ;)

Well, obviously i'm considering this from atheistic pov, so i can't fully appreciate what do christians think about freedom. Though i think this "freedom dichotomy" has rooted in christianity because it plays well with the usual christian dichotomy of body vs soul

> there is one real world connection tho, which is the real scarcity of things when we discuss freedom,

This is another issue. I would probably separate freedom issues into three categories:

- phenomenal freedom (freedom of will; which may posses or not, depending on how the world works)

- external freedom: whether we have phenomenal one or not, we may still be forced by our environment or have a choice

- being informed; while this can be seen as not directly related to freedom, it still is in that the more we know the better strategy of actualizing external freedom we may create

@Moor:

> i think phenomenal and external may be one here as in there is a lot of things that are possible and they relate from the external world with the subject. rationality is a way to learn phenomena and question about the external world.
 
> there is that deterministic aspect of "how the world works" and i do actually believe we live in a deterministic universe

Well, if determinism (or even soft version of it, allowing for random) is true, then phenomenal freedom doesn't exist ;) But whether you think it exists or not (or even that the concept of it makes no sense), i think it's very important to make distinction.

On the contrary to phenomenal, external freedom exist "by definition". Even if it is determined for me to write these lines, we have to access all the information to predict that. Leave out some pieces, and you get indeterminism which would include me not writing (so i have freedom to write or not to write). On the contrary, it suffices to have very basic knowledge to predict that i won't be flying without mechanical help any time soon (so i don't have freedom to fly)

> the first freedom may materialize itself in pure pursuit, e.g: (a) wants (b), (a) pursues (b), (a) may or may not acquire (b).

> on the second (a) considers wanting (b) rationally, it may pursue (b) as a goal but to liberate himself in the process, that is, rationality conduct his expression of freedom.

This has some psychology term, i'm sure, but can't remember what that was.
